Inclusive Design

EEG And Questionnaire Study
To Associate Materiality And Texture With Music Tone
For Sensory Substitution Music Device

Background of the Study

Quite often people associate texture with the quality of vocal or instrumental sounds: “He has metallic voice!” “Uilleann pipes are picturing a golden sunset.” “The music is so silky.”... This research proposal aims to investigate how the materiality and texture of musical instruments can be associated with music tone and how these associations can inform the design of a sensory substitution music device for deaf individuals. According to David Eagleman, our brain processes information but doesn’t care about where the data comes from. Eyes and ears are only external preceptors for information, Sensory substitution is the process of using a different sense (such as touch) to replace or makeup for the lack of another. The findings of this study will have implications for the development of inclusive design for deaf people, particularly in the context of sensory substitution devices for music. To be clear, people with hearing impairment can feel the vibrations, the project is NOT serving as a substitute for hearing but to enhance the experience of music appreciation for them.
